title: CPRA Request: ALPR Audit and Data Sharing

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: CPRA Request: ALPR Audit and Data Sharing
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. Organization Audit in Flock.
The report should include data logged from the period of June 1, 2024, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Organization Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches done within the agency.

2. Network Audit in Flock.
The report should include data logged from the period of June 1, 2024, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Network Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches of the organization’s Flock network by any agency in the Flock System.

3. Data Sharing
a. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares ALPR data
b. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives ALPR data
c. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares “hot list” information
d. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives “hot list” information

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

e

title: Request for Body-worn Camera Footage: Nikolas Acosta (January 06, 2023)

communications.subject: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Request for Body-worn Camera Footage: Nikolas Acosta (January 06, 2023)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All unedited body-worn camera / bodycam recordings related to the following law enforcement critical incident: 

Incident Date: January 06, 2023  
Location: 1200 block of South Michigan Avenue, Roswell, NM  
Victim Name: Nikolas Acosta  

I am specifically requesting the unedited body-worn camera recordings captured by all officers present for the full duration of the incident, including audio recordings associated with the footage.  

If any portion of the requested footage must be redacted, I ask that you clearly indicate the portions that have been redacted and provide an explanation of the legal basis for the redactions. If the requested footage is withheld in its entirety, please provide a detailed explanation citing relevant public records exemption(s).

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 15 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jeffrey Lamson

communications.subject: Re: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Request for Body-worn Camera Footage: Nikolas Acosta (January 06, 2023)
communications.communication:
Good day,
I have received your request for Inspection of Public Records. We are in the process of gathering that information.  I will have a response to you within the time frame designated by the New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act.
Due to the high volume of lapel video and other requests, it may take us longer than normal to provide the requested records.  We hope to have the request completed in a few weeks, but if we can provide the records sooner, we will be in touch.
In response to your inquiry regarding cost, we charge $25 per DVD-R/thumb drive.  If you prefer to utilize our website NextRequest, if the file sizes exceed 2GB there is a $25 free, and if the total file sizes exceed 16GB, the there is a $50 fee.
Sincerely,


Georgia A Davey

Records Supervisor/Records Custodian

Roswell Police Department Records

(575) 624-6770 ext 4184

(575) 624-6780 (fax)



Roswell Police Department

“in pursuit of excellence”

communications.subject: Re: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request #25-403
communications.communication:
Good morning,

Unfortunately we are still working on getting this request completed.  We have been experiencing an extremely high volume of requests the past few months, almost all of which are requests for lapel video.  There are approximately twenty requesters ahead of you, and I only have two people employed full time to work on lapel video review and redaction, one of which was only recently hired in response to the increase in requester volume.

As soon as we can get your request completed I will be in touch with you.  I appreciate your patience and understanding and apologize for the inconvenience.

Thank you.



Georgia A Davey

Records Supervisor/Records Custodian

Roswell Police Department Records

(575) 624-6770 ext 4184

(575) 624-6780 (fax)



Roswell Police Department

“in pursuit of excellence”

communications.subject: Re: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request #25-403
communications.communication:
Good afternoon,

Unfortunately we are still very behind on lapel records requests.  There are still approximately eighteen requesters ahead of you.  We are working as quickly as we can; unfortunately, review and redaction of lapel video is a slow, time consuming process that must be done accurately according to the New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act.

We will do our best to have your request completed, but it will still take a few weeks.  If we are able to complete it sooner, we will definitely be in touch.

Thank you again for you patience and understanding, and we apologize for the extended delay.

Thank you.



Georgia A Davey

Records Supervisor/Records Custodian

Roswell Police Department Records

communications.subject: Oregon Public Records Law Request: Child care provider data
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Oregon Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Historical data on all licensed child care providers (active and closed) from as far back as data systems will allow to present. I also request data on license-exempt providers, if available. Specifically, I request the following information as it is available:

1)	Provider name or ID
2)	Street number
3)	Street name
4)	City
5)	Zip code
6)	Licensed capacity for each year (by child age group if available)
7)	Enrollment for each year (by child age group if available)
8)	Provider type (e.g., center-based provider, home-based provider, Head Start, school-based pre-K, etc.) for each year
9)	First license issue (open) date
10)	Most recent license issue date
11)	Most recent license expiration date or close date
12)	Ages served for each year
13)	Hours of operation for each year
14)	QRIS rating for each year (please explain who is required to participate and whether there are financial supports based on rating)
15)	Accepts Child Care and Development Fund subsidies for each year
16)	Accepts other types of subsidies for each year (please list types)
17)	Prices for each year (by child age group if available)
18)	Violation records

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Gabrielle Pepin

communications.subject: Public Records Request Inquiry 948
communications.communication:

9) First license issue (open) date
10) Most recent license issue date
11) Most recent license expiration date or close date
12) Ages served for each year
13) Hours of operation for each year
14) QRIS rating for each year (please explain who is required to participate and whether there are financial supports based on rating)
15) Accepts Child Care and Development Fund subsidies for each year
16) Accepts other types of subsidies for each year (please list types)
17) Prices for each year (by child age group if available)
18) Violation records

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days. Sincerely, Gabrielle Pepin Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Foregon-department-of-early-learning-and-care-35979%252Fchild-care-provider-data-182223%252F%253Femail%253DKris.REMMY%252540delc.oregon.gov&url_auth_token=AAG3JGu6ZMgu682BXFnl5LQKSvc%3A1tnrjJ%3AwXqf2ORiKbaGpNjOX3xY8XNxkULKYCZZZEAtk3cMUnc”

This is to confirm that DELC is the custodian of the requested records. Before we can proceed, we need some additional clarification.

There are no responsive records to the following data points, as requested:

  *   DELC does not collect, monitor, or track any data on license exempt providers, unless they are a recorded program.
  *   DELC does not monitor or track enrollment.
  *   DELC does monitor some provider types (center-based or home-based), but we do not monitor or track other specific program/service types.
  *   DELC monitors a provider’s acceptance of subsidies only if they are a current participant, so there is no historical data available.
  *   DELC does not monitor or track previous QRIS ratings, only the current QRIS rating of an active/most recent awarding.
  *   DELC does not monitor the price of services offered.

In addition, we are currently unable to determine if there is historical data for the following:

  *   Hours of operation.
  *   Ages served.

Pursuant to Oregon Revised Statues ORS 192.365, your request does not show by clear and convincing evidence that the public interest requires disclosure of the requested information for RF and CF facilities in this particular instance. Therefore, we are only able to share the following information:

     *   Active RF and CF facilities: Facility name and facility city/state/zip.
     *   Active CC facilities: Facility name, full facility address (street and number, city/state/zip).

The request for violation records spanning “as far back as the data systems allow” is denied. The request is too broad, and the information is available on our Child Safety Portal, as found here: Find Child Care Oregon - Find Child Care Oregon<https://findchildcareoregon.org/>

Oregon Revised Statues Referenced:


  *   ORS 192.365: Child care facility operator and exempt family child care provider information (residential address and telephone numbers, personal email addresses, personal cell phone numbers, Social Security numbers, employer-issued identification card numbers, and emergency contact information)

If you would like to proceed with a quote for the portions of your request that are available, please let me know by responding to this email.

Best wishes,
[A picture containing graphics, cartoon  Description automatically generated]
Madison Buck (She/Her)​

communications.subject: RE: Oregon Public Records Law Request: Child care provider data
communications.communication:
Good morning Gabrielle,

I’ve received some feedback from our data team, for most of our historical records capacity is not separated by age group and in some cases was not tracked at all due to changes in license rules over time. We can provide what we have, but it would not be completely representative. If you would like to adjust your request to encompass a smaller time period of data, that would adjust the quote as seen below.

In accordance with ORS 192.324(4)(a), the public body may establish fees reasonably calculated to reimburse the public body for the public body’s actual cost of making public records available, including costs for summarizing, compiling or tailoring the public records, either in organization or media, to meet the request.

The estimate to produce the requested records is as follows (subject to change):

Description
Hours
Hourly Rate
Subtotal
Pull and organize records
1.0


Review and redaction for exempt material
1.0


Total Estimated clerical time
2.0 hours, with the first 30 minutes waived
1.5
$37.50
$37.50


Total Cost
$37.50

DELC requires 50% of the total cost to begin work on this request, which would be $18.75.

We will update this estimate with the actual time it takes to process this request, and the remainder of the cost will be due prior to delivery.

In the event that the actual cost exceeds this estimate, we will contact you for approval to proceed with additional work. Please confirm if you wish to proceed with this request as written, refine your request to reduce the fee, or withdraw your request in its entirety.

If you wish to proceed, please reply to this email and we will send an invoice and payment instructions. If you would like to adjust your request, please let us know.

Best wishes,

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Grievances: Q3 + Q4, Unions
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

1. Provide a list or records regarding all grievance settlements including settlement amounts, union, date grievance filed, school (if applicable), date grievance settled, and contract issues of grievance from July 1, 2024 through December 31, 2024.

2. Provide a list or records regarding all grievances in arbitration including union, date grievance filed, date arbitration started, school (if applicable) and contract issues of grievance from July 1, 2024 through December 31, 2024.

3. Provide a total list of all grievances filed including union, date grievance filed, school (if applicable) and contract issues of grievance from July 1, 2024 to December 31, 2024.

This request is made on behalf of The FOIA Bakery. Because this request is in the public interest for Illinois nonprofit The FOIA Bakery’s work to advocate for public education, please waive any fees in accordance with 5 ILCS § 140/6(c). Feel free to contact me with any questions, or if clarification is needed.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Miriam Bhimani

Chicago Public Schools (CPS) responds to all public records requests in accordance with the Illinois Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq. 
Due to the volume and complexity of requests received in the normal course of business, CPS is extending the time for its initial response to your request by an additional 5 business days (to 10 business days total beginning on the first business day following receipt of the request) pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/3(e)(v) which allows for the examination and evaluation of the requested records by personnel to determine if they are exempt from disclosure under Section 7 of Illinois FOIA or should be revealed only with appropriate deletions. 
Upon the completion of a response, CPS will provide the first 50 pages to you at no charge.  If a response is more than 50 pages, a fee of 15¢ per page will be charged for each additional page. All applicable fees must be paid prior to the copying. CPS will inform you of any fees due if your paper response exceeds 50 pages. You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you’ll receive an email when your request has been completed. Thank you for using the CPS FOIA Center.

communications.subject: Non-Commercial FOIA Request :: N017012-021925
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
April 16, 2025 Miriam Bhimani RE: Chicago Public Schools FOIA Request N017012-021924 Dear Miriam Bhimani: This letter is in reply to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request seeking the following information: 1. Provide a list or records regarding all grievance settlements including settlement amounts, union, date grievance filed, school (if applicable), date grievance settled, and contract issues of grievance from July 1, 2024 through December 31, 2024. RESPONSE: Documents responsive to your request are available to download via the CPS FOIA Center at www.cps.edu/FOIARequests . Please log in with your username and password to access the records. The District is prohibited by law from releasing employee performance evaluation information in accordance with 105 ILCS 5/24A-7.1, which prohibits the release of teacher, principal and superintendent performance evaluations, as well as 820 ILCS 40/11, which prohibits the release of performance evaluations for public employees. 
2. Provide a list or records regarding all grievances in arbitration including union, date grievance filed, date arbitration started, school (if applicable) and contract issues of grievance from July 1, 2024 through December 31, 2024. 
RESPONSE : Documents responsive to your request are available to download via the CPS FOIA Center at www.cps.edu/FOIARequests . Please log in with your username and password to access the records. The records provided include all grievances received by the Labor & Employee Discipline Unit only. Additionally, be advised that the CPS FOIA office determined that this portion of your request is categorical in nature as it does not reasonably identify a document for search, and the collection of this information would require the District to create records. Specifically, the CPS does not comprehensively track the requested information in the manner requested, in the normal course of business. As such fulfilling this request would be considered creating records which is not required pursuant to the FOIA. Specifically, in order to comply with your request, each and every file would have to be pulled and all the portions of information you have requested would have to be searched for. Essentially, a new record would have to be created. This process is not required according to guidance provided by 5 ILCS 140/2(c). 5 ILCS 140/1, Kenyon v. Garrels, 184 Ill. App. 3d 28, 32 (4 th Dist. 1989), and Yeager v. Drug Enforcement Admin., 678 F. 2d 315, 321 (D.C. Cir. 1982). Additionally, under Illinois FOIA law, a request to inspect or copy a record must reasonably identify a public record, as opposed to general data, information or statistics to be gleaned from documents which have not otherwise been created by a public body. Accordingly, FOIA applies to the provision of existing public records; a public body is not required to answer questions or generate new records in response to a FOIA request. Further, Section 1 of the FOIA states in part: "This Act is not intended to create an obligation on the part of any public body to maintain or prepare any public record which was not maintained or prepared by such public body at the time when this Act becomes effective, except as otherwise required by applicable local, State or federal law." In accordance with Section 1 of Illinois FOIA, the District is not required to conduct research to answer questions or prepare researched records in response to a specific query [5 ILCS 140/1]. 3. Provide a total list of all grievances filed including union, date grievance filed, school (if applicable) and contract issues of grievance from July 1, 2024 to December 31, 2024. RESPONSE : Documents responsive to your request are available to download via the CPS FOIA Center at www.cps.edu/FOIARequests . Please log in with your username and password to access the records. The records provided include all grievances received by the Office of Administrative Hearings only. As to the remainder of all other potentially responsive data, the CPS FOIA office has determined that it is categorical in nature as it does not reasonably identify a document for search, and the collection of this information would require the District to create records. Specifically, the CPS does not comprehensively track the requested information in the manner requested, in the normal course of business. As such fulfilling this request would be considered creating records which is not required pursuant to the FOIA. Specifically, in order to comply with your request, each and every file would have to be pulled and all the portions of information you have requested would have to be searched for. Essentially, a new record would have to be created. This process is not required according to guidance provided by 5 ILCS 140/2(c). 5 ILCS 140/1, Kenyon v. Garrels, 184 Ill. App. 3d 28, 32 (4 th Dist. 1989), and Yeager v. Drug Enforcement Admin., 678 F. 2d 315, 321 (D.C. Cir. 1982). Additionally, under Illinois FOIA law, a request to inspect or copy a record must reasonably identify a public record, as opposed to general data, information or statistics to be gleaned from documents which have not otherwise been created by a public body. Accordingly, FOIA applies to the provision of existing public records; a public body is not required to answer questions or generate new records in response to a FOIA request. Further, Section 1 of the FOIA states in part: "This Act is not intended to create an obligation on the part of any public body to maintain or prepare any public record which was not maintained or prepared by such public body at the time when this Act becomes effective, except as otherwise required by applicable local, State or federal law." In accordance with Section 1 of Illinois FOIA, the District is not required to conduct research to answer questions or prepare researched records in response to a specific query [5 ILCS 140/1]. To the extent you consider this a denial, pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/9.5(a) you may file a Request for Review with the Public Access Counselor (PAC) at: Public Access Counselor; Office of the Attorney General; 500 South 2nd Street; Springfield, IL 62706. You also have the right to seek judicial review of your denial by filing a lawsuit in the State circuit court, 5 ILCS 140/11. If you choose to file a Request for Review with the PAC, you must do so within 60 calendar days of the date of this denial letter. 5 ILCS 140/9.5(a). Please note that you must include a copy of your original FOIA request and this denial letter when filing a Request for Review with the PAC. If you have any questions, please contact our office at (773) 553-3500. 
Thank you for your request. Sincerely, 
Ana Diaz Freedom of Information Act Officer Chicago Public Schools

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Daniel Mortality Review
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of the IHSC Mortality Review for Charles Leo Daniel, who died in ICE Custody March 7, 2024, according to the Detainee Death Report ICE published: https://www.ice.gov/doclib/foia/reports/ddrDanielCharlesLeo.pdf.

I make this request as a member of the media, and therefore seek a fee waiver. Representative edited works based on prior FOIA requests like this one may be reviewed here: https://theappeal.org/authors/andrew-free/; and here: https://atlpresscollective.com/2025/01/31/new-record-sheds-light-on-unreported-death-in-atlanta-airport-customs-inspection/. 

I request expedited processing of this request pursuant to 6 CFR 5.5(e) and attest under penalty of perjury pursuant to 28 USC 1746 that the following statements are true and correct to the best of my knowledge and understanding: 
1. ICE deaths in custody in FY25 are currently on track to equal or surpass the 12 deaths in the previous fiscal year. 

2. IHSC Mortality Reviews provide an authoritative agency accounting of the medical circumstances of in-custody deaths. These reviews often conflict with the public-facing story the agency tells, raising critical questions about accountability, transparency, waste, fraud, and abuse. See https://phr.org/our-work/resources/deadly-failures-preventable-deaths-in-u-s-immigration-detention/.

3. The current administration's expansion of federal immigration detention is the subject of widespread and exceptional media interest in which there exist possible questions about the government's integrity which affect public confidence. See, e.g., 
a. https://www.newyorker.com/news/the-lede/how-many-immigrants-will-die-in-us-custody
b. https://www.reviewjournal.com/news/politics-and-government/nevada/ice-increases-detention-capacity-in-southern-nevada-3318591/&ct=ga&cd=CAEYAioTODA4NDM3NjM3MDcwNDg3MjU0NDIaMzU4OGE4OGMwMWViNjNlYTpjb206ZW46VVM&usg=AOvVaw0AY_z02AvW4eN7-HW7Pbvr
c. https://www.reviewjournal.com/news/politics-and-government/nevada/ice-increases-detention-capacity-in-southern-nevada-3318591/

e. https://latenighter.com/news/john-oliver-shares-chilling-details-about-ice-detention/
f. https://www.bisnow.com/national/news/capital-markets/private-prison-firms-predict-unprecedented-growth-from-trumps-immigration-crackdown-128291
g. https://www.wkbn.com/news/local-news/youngstown-news/corecivic-trying-to-add-space-for-ice-detainees/
h. https://prismreports.org/2025/01/15/biden-immigration-migrant-deaths/

n. https://www.aclufl.org/en/press-releases/three-deaths-ice-custody-just-over-month-trumps-presidency-marks-most-deaths-occur
o. https://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/nation/privately-run-immigration-detention-center-that-previously-held-families-in-texas-will-reopen/

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

communications.subject: ICE FOIA 2025-ICFO-25069
communications.communication:
03/13/2025 

Andrew  Free 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR182996 
Boston, Massachusetts 02115 

RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2025-ICFO-25069 
 
Dear Requester: 

This acknowledges receipt of your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), dated 3/13/2025, your request for a waiver of all assessable FOIA fees, and your request for expedited treatment. Your request was received in this office on 3/13/2025. Specifically, you have requested records pertaining to A copy of the IHSC Mortality Review for Charles Leo Daniel, who died in ICE Custody March 7, 2024, according to the Detainee Death Report ICE published: https://www.ice.gov/doclib/foia/reports/ddrDanielCharlesLeo.pdf.. 

Due to the increasing number of FOIA requests received by this office, we may encounter some delay in processing your request. Per Section 5.5(a) of the DHS FOIA regulations, 6 C.F.R. Part 5, ICE processes FOIA requests according to their order of receipt. Although ICE’s goal is to respond within 20 business days of receipt of your request, the FOIA does permit a 10-day extension of this time period. As your request seeks numerous documents that will necessitate a thorough and wide-ranging search, ICE will invoke a 10-day extension for your request, as allowed by Title 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(B). If you’re able to narrow the scope of your request please contact our office. Narrowing the scope may speed up the search process. We will make every effort to comply with your request in a timely manner. 

ICE evaluates fee waiver requests under the legal standard set forth above and the fee waiver policy guidance issued by the Department of Justice on April 2, 1987, as incorporated into the Department of Homeland Security’s Freedom of Information Act regulations.  These regulations set forth six factors to examine in determining whether the applicable legal standard for fee waiver has been met.  I have considered the following factors in my evaluation of your request for a fee waiver: 

(1) Whether the subject of the requested records concerns “the operations or activities of the government”; 
(2) Whether the disclosure is “likely to contribute” to an understanding of government operations or activities; 
(3) Whether disclosure of the requested information will contribute to the understanding of the public at large, as opposed to the individual understanding of the requestor or a narrow segment of interested persons; 
(4) Whether the contribution to public understanding of government operations or activities will be "significant"; 
(5) Whether the requester has a commercial interest that would be furthered by the requested disclosure; and 
(6) Whether the magnitude of any identified commercial interest to the requestor is sufficiently large in comparison with the public interest in disclosure, that disclosure is primarily in the commercial interest of the requestor. 

Upon review of your request and a careful consideration of the factors listed above, I have determined to grant your request for a fee waiver. 

Your request for expedited treatment is hereby denied. 

Under the DHS FOIA regulations, expedited processing of a FOIA request is warranted if the request involves “circumstances in which the lack of expedited treatment could reasonably be expected to pose an imminent threat to the life or physical safety of an individual,” 6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(1)(i), or “an urgency to inform the public about an actual or alleged federal government activity, if made by a person primarily engaged in disseminating information,” 6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(l)(ii).  Requesters seeking expedited processing must submit a statement explaining in detail the basis for the request, and that statement must be certified by the requester to be true and correct.  6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(3). 

Your request for expedited processing is denied because you do not qualify for either category under 6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(1).  You failed to demonstrate a particular urgency to inform the public about the government activity involved in the request beyond the public’s right to know about government activity generally.  Your letter was conclusory in nature and did not present any facts to justify a grant of expedited processing under the applicable standards. 

If you deem the decision to deny expedited treatment of your request an adverse determination, you have the right to appeal.  Should you wish to do so, you must send your appeal and a copy of this letter, within 90 days of the date of this letter following the procedures outlined in the DHS FOIA regulations at 6 C.F.R. Part 5 § 5.5(e)(2). You may submit your appeal electronically at GILDFOIAAppeals@ice.dhs.gov or via regular mail to: 

U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement 
Office of the Principal Legal Advisor 
U.S. Department of Homeland Security 
500 12th Street,, S.W., Mail Stop 5900 
Washington, D.C. 20536-5900 

Your envelope and letter should be marked “FOIA Appeal.”  Copies of the FOIA and DHS regulations are available at www.dhs.gov/foia. 

ICE has queried the appropriate program offices within ICE for responsive records. If any responsive records are located, they will be reviewed for determination of releasability. Please be assured that one of the processors in our office will respond to your request as expeditiously as possible. We appreciate your patience as we proceed with your request. 

If you have any questions please contact FOIA Public Liaison Daniel Edgington, at (866) 633-1182 or 500 12th St, SW Stop 5009 Washington, DC 20536-5009. Additionally, you have a right to seek dispute resolution services from the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) which mediates disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusive alternative to litigation.  If you are requesting access to your own records (which is considered a Privacy Act request), you should know that OGIS does not have the authority to handle requests made under the Privacy Act of 1974.  You may contact OGIS as follows:  Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448. 

Your request has been assigned reference number 2025-ICFO-25069. Please use this number in future correspondence. 

Sincerely, 

ICE FOIA Office 
Immigration and Customs Enforcement 
Freedom of Information Act Office 
500 12th Street, S.W., Stop 5009 
Washington, D.C. 20536-5009

Andrew  Free 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR182996 
Boston, Massachusetts 02115 

RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2025-ICAP-00166 

Dear Requester: 

The Department of Homeland Security has received your letter appealing the adverse determination of your Freedom of Information Act/Privacy Act (FOIA/PA) request by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement. Your appeal, dated 3/14/2025, was received on 3/26/2025. 

The Government Information Law Division acknowledges your appeal request of and is assigning it number 2025-ICAP-00166 for tracking purposes.  Please reference this number in any future communications about your appeal. 

A high number of FOIA/PA requests have been received by the Department.  Accordingly, we have adopted the court-sanctioned practice of generally handling backlogged appeals on a first-in, first-out basis.   While we will make every effort to process your appeal on a timely basis, there may be some delay in resolving this matter.  Should you have any questions concerning the processing of your appeal, please contact Daniel Edgington ICE FOIA Office/Public Liaison at (866) 633-1182 or at 500 12th St., SW Washington, DC 20536-5009. 

Sincerely, 
 
Sara Jazayeri 
Chief 
Government Information Law Division 
ICE Office of the Principal Legal Advisor 
U.S. Department of Homeland Security

communications.subject: Welcome to the City of Chicago Request Center!
communications.communication:
Dear Joey  Scott, 
 
 
Thank you for registering with the City of Chicago Public Records Portal. 
If you did not submit your request through the public portal but are receiving this e-mail, we are excited to share with you that you can now submit FOIA requests through a newly implemented online request system. While you will still be allowed to email your FOIA requests, creating an account and submitting your request online will allow you to check the online portal for the status of requests. You will also receive an email when the records are ready to be downloaded.

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: PRR  Los Angeles City Attorney
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Please See enclosed PDF

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Maxine Doogan

communications.subject: Re: California Public Records Act Request: PRR Los Angeles City Attorney
communications.communication:
Good morning,

I just wanted to circle back on this production given that our next
deadline was approaching next week. We have completed our search and have
identified potentially responsive records pursuant to your request. An
initial review was performed of these documents and we are just waiting for
the director of the Figueroa Corridor Human Trafficking Project to conduct
a final review of these documents. Unfortunately, I was just informed that
he is out of the office on paternity leave through March 17 and will not be
able to begin his review until that time.

My apologies for the continued delay. I will reach out to you on or before
March 17, 2025 with our revised production date. Thank you again for your
patience and understanding.

best regards,
Frank Mateljan

-- 
*Frank T. Mateljan III*
Office of the City Attorney

CPRA Unit - General Counsel Division

200 N. Main Street, Suite 800

Los Angeles, CA 90012

communications.subject: Re: California Public Records Act Request: PRR Los Angeles City Attorney
communications.communication:
Good afternoon,

As previously discussed, I am circling back with you to provide an update
as to the status of the review of the documents you requested. The
director of the Figueroa Corridor Human Trafficking Project has returned to
the office and will begin reviewing the potentially responsive documents we
have identified. We estimate this review will take approximately two weeks
given he is returning from an extended absence and will need time to catch
up on other outstanding matters as well. We will touch base on or before *April
1, 2025* to finalize production.

Thank you again for your continued patience and understanding.

best,
Frank Mateljan

--

communications.subject: Pennsylvania Right to Know Act Request: Anne Gibbs & K9 Hero Haven
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Pennsylvania Right to Know Act, I hereby request the following records:

All public records pertaining to animal cruelty investigations and any related enforcement actions conducted by the Pennsylvania Department of Agriculture, Bureau of Animal Health and Diagnostic Services, concerning the following:
    ▪︎ Anne Gibbs
    ▪︎ K9 Hero Haven, identified as #15949
    ▪︎ 176 Mahanoy Creek Lane, Herndon, PA 17830

This request encompasses, but is not limited to, all records of complaints received, inspection reports, investigative files, and any other documents generated or compiled by the Bureau in connection with said investigations. Specifically, the request seeks records covering the period from JANUARY 1, 2023, to the PRESENT DATE.

A waiver of all applicable fees associated with this request is respectfully requested. The disclosure of these records is demonstrably in the public interest, as it pertains to potential animal cruelty within an animal rescue organization. The release of this information would significantly contribute to public understanding of the oversight and operations of such organizations, thereby promoting animal welfare and fostering accountability within the community. This request is not predicated upon a commercial interest, but rather seeks to ensure the welfare of animals and promote transparency in the handling of animal cruelty complaints.

Expedited processing of this request is respectfully requested due to the potential ongoing nature of the alleged animal welfare concerns and the necessity for prompt action. Animal cruelty investigations are inherently time-sensitive, and delays in access to pertinent information may adversely affect ongoing investigations and the safety and well-being of the animals involved.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jonathan Colon

title: Ossining Police Department Twitter Block List

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Ossining Police Department Twitter Block List
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Ossining Police Department
88 Spring Street
Ossining, NY 10562

Dear Freedom of Information Act Officer,

Subject: Freedom of Information Act Request

I hope this letter finds you well. Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 U.S.C. § 552, I am requesting access to the list of Twitter profiles blocked by the Ossining Police Department's official Twitter account (@OssiningPolice).

To assist you in locating these records, please follow the steps below to view the blocked profiles:

Log into the @OssiningPolice Twitter account.
Click on 'More' in the menu on the left-hand side.
Click on 'Settings and privacy'.
Select 'Privacy and safety'.
Scroll down to 'Safety' and click on 'Blocked accounts'. Here, you will find the list of all blocked profiles.
Given that these records relate to a public department's social media, which is utilized for communication with and among the public, they should fall within the purview of the Freedom of Information Act.

I would like to draw your attention to two cases related to social media blocking and the First Amendment. The first is Knight First Amendment Institute v. Trump (2017), where the court found that blocking users from an official's Twitter account, which is used as a public forum, is a violation of their First Amendment rights. The second is Davison v. Randall (2019), where the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals extended this reasoning to local officials.

While these cases deal with blocking individuals on Twitter, they provide the legal context under which public officials and departments must operate when considering whether to block individuals from their social media accounts.

Given these precedents, the block list of the Ossining Police Department's Twitter account should constitute disclosable public records under the FOIA as they pertain to potential infringements on First Amendment activity.

If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

communications.subject: New Jersey Open Public Records Act Request: Crime Incidents Request
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New Jersey Open Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting data on crime incidents—those classified by your agency as crimes—rather than calls for service or unfounded incidents.
• Year(s) Requested: 2013, 2015, 2018, 2023 
• Columns Requested: Incident date, Incident time, Type of crime (e.g., robbery, theft, etc.), Incident ID, and all other available columns that do not require additional processing by the agency or redaction.

If the data are stored in a proprietary or custom electronic format not publicly available, I request that it be converted to a format viewable with standard software, such as Microsoft Excel or CSV. Please avoid providing data in PDF or paper printouts.

This request is made to support academic research conducted in the public interest and is not for commercial purposes. The data will contribute to a research project assessing the effect of music concerts on crime, aiming to enhance public understanding of how large events influence community safety.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kristina Block

title: Hegseth (Dept of the Army US Army Human Resources Command)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Hegseth (Dept of the Army US Army Human Resources Command)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

The files provided to Eric Levai in response to his FOIA request on Pete Hegseth.

On January 21, 2021, Levai sent a request to the National Guard Bureau via the website MuckRock for "Military records for Fox News host Pete Hegseth, who joined the Army National Guard in 2003. I would like anything publicly disclosable under FOIA." The National Guard Bureau transferred his request to the Army Human Resources Command. (See the attached letter.) On February 2, 2021, the Army Human Resources Command sent Levai responsive records.

I am requesting a copy of those records.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matthew Petti

The requested records have been posted to the Army FOIA Library for public review and download. You may access the file by following these directions:

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FTC layoffs
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Hi,

I am seeking a list of all terminations between 1/1/2025 and present. If possible, I would prefer data clarify which terminations were reductions in force and which staff were probationary or term-limited.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tonya Riley

title: California Public Records Request-IMSI - Catcher Equipment

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: California Public Records Request-IMSI - Catcher Equipment
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Per the California Public Records Act (Govt. Code 6250-6270), I am writing to request the following information from the los angeles police department for the period July 29, 2016, to the date of this letter.

All correspondence , including all contracts , emails , text messages , phone calls logs regarding IMSI-catcher or cell phone interception devices (commonly called stingrays or hailstorms) involving the los angeles police department , American Automobile Association  , L3 technologies inc , harris corporation inc , tactical support equipment inc , octastic inc , .

Number, if any, of IMSI-catcher or cell phone interception devices (commonly called stingrays or hailstorms) available for use by the los angeles police department or agency via collaborative agreements that were utilized within the period encompassing this request. Please provide the name of the department or agency that made IMSI-catcher devices available to los angeles police department or agency for use.

Any documents or correspondence during the period encompassing this request regarding possible or planned acquisition of an IMSI-catcher device.

Any existing or proposed usage policies regarding the use of cell phone interception technology including protocols, training documents and data storage procedures.

Any current or past litigation involving or referencing the los angeles police department or agency involving the use of cell phone interception technology.

Please notify me when this information is available.

Thank you for your attention to this request and for your prompt reply within 10 days.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Mr. adonis gaynor

communications.subject: [External Message Added] City of Los Angeles public records request #25-725
communications.communication:
City of Los Angeles ************************************************************************ A message was sent to you regarding record request #25-725: Dear Requester:   We received your request for:   * "All correspondence , including all contracts , emails , text messages , phone calls logs regarding IMSI-catcher or cell phone interception devices (commonly called stingrays or hailstorms) involving the los angeles police department , American Automobile Association , L3 technologies inc , harris corporation inc , tactical support equipment inc , octastic inc , . * Number, if any, of IMSI-catcher or cell phone interception devices (commonly called stingrays or hailstorms) available for use by the los angeles police department or agency via collaborative agreements that were utilized within the period encompassing this request. Please provide the name of the department or agency that made IMSI-catcher devices available to los angeles police department or agency for use. * Any documents or correspondence during the period encompassing this request regarding possible or planned acquisition of an IMSI-catcher device. * Any existing or proposed usage policies regarding the use of cell phone interception technology including protocols, training documents and data storage procedures. * Any current or past litigation involving or referencing the los angeles police department or agency involving the use of cell phone interception technology."   Your request was made under the California Public Records Act (the Act). The Department is cognizant of its responsibilities under the Act. It recognizes the statutory scheme was enacted to maximize citizen access to the workings of government. The Act does not mandate disclosure of all documents within the government’s possession. Rather, by specific exemption and reference to other statutes, the Act recognizes that there are boundaries where the public’s right to access must be balanced against such weighty considerations as the right of privacy, a right of constitutional dimension under California Constitution, Article 1, Section 1. The law also exempts from disclosure records that are privileged or confidential or otherwise exempt under either express provisions of the Act or pursuant to applicable federal or state law, per California Government Code Sections 7927.200; 7927.700; 7923.600-7923.625; 7927.705; and 7922.000.   In regard to all correspondence, emails, and text messages, please provide Department employee names or serial numbers, email addresses or domains, and keywords so that the Department may conduct a focused search for records responsive to this portion of your request. Please be advised that the Department's search capabilities for text messages are restricted to individual devices.   We ask that you provide a response by January 29, 2025. If we do not receive a response by the date indicated, then we will consider this request closed.   In regard to contracts, number of IMSI-catcher or cell phone interception devices available for use, and existing usage policies, please be advised that, pursuant to California Government Code Section 7922.535, we have found that “unusual circumstances” exist with respect to the request due to the need to search for, collect, and review the requested records from other Department entities which are separate from the office processing the request. Therefore, we will require the statutory fourteen days extension of time in which to respond. A determination concerning your request will be made as soon as possible.   In regard to phone call logs, the Department does not maintain the records you are seeking regarding this portion of your request.   In regard to items 3 and 5, please note that these portions of your request is broad and does not reasonably and clearly describe the records sought to permit the Department to conduct a reasonable search for responsive records, as required by Government Code Section 7922.530. Please submit additional information (type of document or type of correspondence) to assist with the search. Please respond by no later than January 29, 2025, if you wish to proceed. If we do not receive a response by the date indicated, we will consider these portions of your request closed.   If parts of your request seeks records detailing a deliberative process, please note that pursuant to Government Code 7922.000, the Department asserts an exemption over records that consist of or contain deliberative discussions, notes, and drafts. Section 7922.000 permits the non-disclosure of such records and information when “the public interest served by not disclosing the record and/or information, clearly outweighs the public interest served by disclosure.” Therefore, responsive records that consist of or contain deliberative discussions, notes, and drafts are exempt from disclosure.   If you have any questions, please respond to this email.   Respectfully,   LAPD Public Records & Subpoena Response Section, CPRA Unit ************************************************************************ Questions about your request? Reply to this email or sign in to contact staff at City of Los Angeles.
Technical support: See our help page

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request #25-725
communications.communication:
the following are 3-5 explain what is broad and does not reasonably and clearly describe the records sought:

regarding any documents or correspondence during the period encompassing this request regarding possible or planned acquisition of an IMSI-catcher device.

Any existing or proposed usage policies regarding the use of cell phone interception technology including protocols, training documents and data storage procedures.

Any current or past litigation involving or referencing the los Angeles police department or agency involving the use of cell phone interception technology.

Reminder: Any attempt to circumvent any portion of this request pursuant to this act, will result in stringent legal consequences. Thank you, Mr. Adonis Gaynor.

communications.subject: [External Message Added] City of Los Angeles public records request #25-725
communications.communication:
City of Los Angeles ************************************************************************ A message was sent to you regarding record request #25-725: Dear Requester:   We received your message, dated January 26, 2025.   In regard to all correspondence, emails, and text messages, the Department has not received the additional information that we requested by January 29, 2025, which is required to accurately respond to this portion of your request. We are closing this portion request.   In regard to item 3 and proposed usage policies, please note that the records you seek are exempt from disclosure pursuant to Government Code 7922.000. The Department asserts an exemption over records that consist of or contain deliberative discussions, notes, and drafts. Section 7922.000 permits the non-disclosure of such records and information when “the public interest served by not disclosing the record and/or information, clearly outweighs the public interest served by disclosure.” Therefore, responsive records, if any, that consist of or contain deliberative discussions, notes, and drafts are exempt from disclosure.   In regard to item 5, your request for "litigation" is not “a request for a copy of records that reasonably describes an identifiable record or records” [see Government Code Section 7922.530(a)]. The Department has not received the additional information that we requested by January 29, 2025, which is required to accurately respond to this portion of your request. We are closing this portion request.   In regard to contracts, the Department has conducted a search based on the information provided and no responsive records were located.    In regard to the number of IMSI-catcher or cell phone interception devices available for use and existing usage policies, please note that our office—the LAPD Public Records and Subpoena Response Section, CPRA Unit—does not house the records you are seeking. The Department is in the process of searching for the requested records. Please note that some of the records to be provided, if any, may be redacted pursuant to California Government Code Sections 7927.200; 7927.700; 7923.600-7923.625; 7927.705; and 7922.000. We will provide an update by March 12, 2025, and will notify you should anything change.    If you have any questions, please respond to this email.   Respectfully,   LAPD Public Records & Subpoena Response Section, CPRA Unit ************************************************************************ Questions about your request? Reply to this email or sign in to contact staff at City of Los Angeles.
Technical support: See our help page

communications.subject: Your City of Los Angeles public records request #25-725 has been closed.
communications.communication:
City of Los Angeles ************************************************************************ Record request #25-725 has been closed. The closure reason supplied was: Dear Requester:   In regard to the number of IMSI-catcher or cell phone interception devices, with regard to Section 7922.000, the Department has a strong interest in maintaining the confidentiality of records that consist of or contain detailed operational and deployment information. Disclosure of this information to the public has the potential to enable would-be perpetrators to discern areas of vulnerability and evade security procedures, thereby endangering the operation of the Department and the safety of its officers and the public. Therefore, the information you seek is exempt from disclosure.    In regard to usage policies, the Department has completed its review and is providing you with the record responsive to your request.   Additionally, please see the Department Manual, Volume 3, Section 568.55, for additional records responsive to your request.   If you have any questions, please respond to this email.   Respectfully,   LAPD Public Records & Subpoena Response Section, CPRA Unit ************************************************************************ Questions about your request? Reply to this email or sign in to contact staff at City of Los Angeles.
Technical support: See our help page

communications.subject: Welcome to the Records Center!

communications.subject: Public Records Request :: Y030846-041425
communications.communication:
Dear Rose Terse: 
 
Thank you for your interest in public records of Yakima County.   Your request was given the reference number Y030846-041425 for tracking purposes. 
 
You submitted a public records request to Yakima County asking for: 
 To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All current "Brady lists" and "Giglio lists" (per Brady v. Maryland/Giglio v. United States) maintained by your office.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

 If Yakima County has registered, you in our Records Center: 
 
The email address you have provided to us will be your login. Please login to the Records Center to update any contact information, change your password and to track the progress of your request. The link to our Records Center and a link to request a temporary password is provided to you below. 
 
Please allow Yakima County 5 days to respond to this request. 
 
If you have any questions, please feel free to contact us at 509-574-1200. 
 
Yakima County Records Center: 
 
Thank you for using the Yakima County Request Center.

 04/15/2025 
Rose Terse MuckRock News, DEPT MR184781 263 Huntington Ave Boston, MA 02115 RE: Records Request: Y030846-041425 
Dear Rose Terse: 
You submitted a public records request to Yakima County asking for: "To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records: 

All current "Brady lists" and "Giglio lists" (per Brady v. Maryland/Giglio v. United States) maintained by your office. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Rose Terse 

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fyakima-county-prosecuting-attorney-35223%252Fbrady-list-april-2025-yakima-county-prosecuting-attorney-184781%252F%253Femail%253Dprosecuting.attorney%252540co.yakima.wa.us&url_auth_token=AAGlfDAQFYhXfxnXcbalGffKFug%3A1u4VhC%3A4JXbF5v_qoJX5Lf-GGuR4Z2kS-bZTZXAYTVY4bBsB88" 
After a diligent search, Yakima County has located records responsive to your request. These records have been uploaded to your Records Center. Click the link below this message to login and retrieve the records. This is Yakima County’s final and definitive response to your public records request. Your request is complete and will now be closed. The date of this letter starts the one-year statute of limitations. This means you have one year from the date of this letter to file a lawsuit if you believe we have not fulfilled our responsibilities under the Public Records Act, pursuant to RCW 42.56.550(6 ). Please feel free to reach out if you have any questions and or if we have misunderstood your request. Yakima County strives to provide the greatest assistance possible and wants to ensure you receive all the records you are seeking. If we need to communicate further after this letter, we will inform you if a new date is needed or if the date of this letter will remain for the statute of limitations. Sincerely, 

Patricia Andersen

title: Video and Audio and electronic files Wisconsin (Wisconsin Department of Justice)

communications.subject: Wisconsin Open Records Act Request: Video and Audio and electronic files Wisconsin (Wisconsin Department of Justice)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Wisconsin Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am looking for the following records : 

(To clarify I am not looking for any records that are contained in the discovery files or discs that are already available.) 

I am looking for records pertaining to and for criminal case 2014CF000860 and the folllowing individuals : 
Kristopher Paul Torgerson 10/27/1979

Stephanie Ann Low 09/29/1988

The time scale for this is from September 2010 to March 2017. 

I am looking for the following any electronic files such as emails involving the two names. Any video files involving the two names. Any audio files involving the two names.  Any digital files. Any scanned letters or mail. 

If the request is too burdensome or broad please send me a list of the files you have so I can choose the relevant files from that list. 

I would ask that they be sent via email or email link. Or if not please let me know if the cost goes above $50 to send via shipping.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Emma

communications.subject: RE: Wisconsin Open Records Act Request: Video and Audio and electronic files Wisconsin (Wisconsin Department of Justice)
communications.communication:
Good morning,



The Wisconsin Department of Justice (DOJ) construes your correspondence as a public records request pursuant to the Wisconsin Public Records Law, Wis. Stat. §§ 19.31 to 19.39. We have initiated a review of our files in order to respond to your request.



Wisconsin Statutes mandate that we provide you with a response “as soon as practicable and without delay.” Wis. Stat. § 19.35(4)(a). DOJ is committed to providing a thorough and timely response to your request.



Thank you,

[cid:image001.png@01DB2082.7A088E60]
State of Wisconsin Department of Justice
Office of Open Government
17 W. Main Street
Madison, WI 53703
opengov@widoj.gov<mailto:opengov@widoj.gov>
Phone: (608) 267-2220

title: Amtrak Board of Directors - Meeting Agendas and Minutes | Dec 2024 (2nd request)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Amtrak Board of Directors - Meeting Agendas and Minutes | Dec 2024 (2nd request)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

The agenda and minutes for any meeting of the Amtrak Board of Directors that occurred in the month of December 2024, including the meetings that were scheduled to be held on December 4th and December 5th.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ben Heckscher

title: Correctional Officers as Truancy Officers (Hampden County Sheriff's Office)

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Correctional Officers as Truancy Officers (Hampden County Sheriff's Office)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Records that detail the extent to which correctional officers and other Sheriff Department employees act as truancy officers from January 1, 2023 to the time this request is filled. Specifically, I request records that show the name and title of sheriff department employees who act as truancy officers, the school districts where they have worked, and any training or certification that the employee has received related to work as a truancy officer.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joshua Dankoff

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: VR Police (Santa Ana Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records related to the department's procurement or purchase of VR training equipment:
- Brochures, marketing materials including videos and demonstrations, PowerPoints from VR companies
- Invoices, Contracts, and Proposals from VR companies
- Grant requests to purchase or trial VR software and hardware
- Emails related to meetings, presentations, demonstrations, or conference appointments with VR companies. 
Search 2020 to 2024

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joey Scott

City of Santa Ana ************************************************************************ Your record request #25-798 has been submitted successfully. This will acknowledge that the City of Santa Ana received your Public Records Act request. The City will respond to your request within ten (10) days of receipt of this request in accordance with the California Public Records Act. Pursuant to the Email and Text Message Retention Policy of the City, all emails and text messages are retained for two (2) years and deleted on a rolling basis thereafter. Please be advised, Public Records Requests are only reviewed during regular business hours, from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. Monday through Thursday and alternating Fridays.  Visit the online Holiday and Closed Friday Schedule at https://www.santa-ana.org/holiday-and-closed-friday-schedule ************************************************************************ Reply to this email or sign in to contact City of Santa Ana.

communications.communication:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All current "Brady lists" and "Giglio lists" (per Brady v. Maryland/Giglio v. United States) maintained by your office.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

title: OIG Report on IJ who sent fake email from EOIR Director and slept with a subordinate

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: OIG Report on IJ who sent fake email from EOIR Director and slept with a subordinate
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

The complete report described in this summary: https://oig.justice.gov/reports/investigative-summary-findings-misconduct-then-acting-assistant-chief-immigration-judge

The summary describes an acting ACIJ who was accused of having had an inappropriate relationship with a subordinate. It also says that when the acting ACIJ was an IJ, he sent a fake email purporting to be from the EOIR Director to a third party. This is deeply concerning. Immigrants ordered removed by this person have a right to know if he is a biased adjudicator and if anything he did might reflect bias that would have affected their removal proceedings. Accordingly, we intend to obtain through the FOIA and publish the full report.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matthew Hoppock

Attached is the OIG's acknowledgment of your FOIA request. 

Please note we may require additional time to process your request as we are experiencing a significant FOIA backlog. 
We will continue to process requests as expeditiously as possible. 

Thank you. 
Office of General Counsel/OIG

files.source: Department of Justice, Office of the Inspector General, United States of America

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #24-OIG-415
communications.communication:
Hi Ms. Waller. I received the status update and I am confused. The update references multiple documents being compiled. However, my FOIA only asked for one document - the report referenced in this summary: https://oig.justice.gov/reports/investigative-summary-findings-misconduct-then-acting-assistant-chief-immigration-judge. As I understand it, the report is a single document that is subject to public disclosure and should have been disclosed at the outset. What is more, the statutory deadline has passed. Please confirm that we are not talking about a host of documents that the agency needs to sort through and redact, as I have only requested one document. And inasmuch as you confirm that you have that document in your possession, please produce it post haste. Thank you. 

Matthew Hoppock.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #24-OIG-415
communications.communication:
For clarification, we are currently processing the requested record, and we apologize for any confusion our interim response letter may have caused.

Thank you.
